title: Is an acknowledgment for a memoir book typically in the beginning or in the end? - Quora
tags: History of the United States of America

response.answer_text: Are acknowledgments for memoirs typically in the beginning or end? I’ve seen them done both ways. Memoirists might include acknowledgements in their book’s introduction or preface, or under such rubrics as “notes.” Some memoirists write acknowledgments with no formal heading. T.E. Lawrence does that in Seven Pillars of Wisdom, thanking Mr and Mrs Bernard Shaw “for countless suggestions of great value and diversity: and for all the present semi-colons.” Robert Graves ended the first edition of Goodbye to All That (1929) with a paean to his muse titled, “Dedicatory Epilogue to Laura Riding.” It’s missing from the second (and now standard) edition of Graves’s autobiography, published in 1957. Confessions of An Advertising Man, David Ogilvy’s sly new business pitch masquerading as a memoir, has acknowledgments under the heading “Background,” in the front of the book. Ulysses S. Grant included his acknowledgments in the preface of his classic autobiography. Grant wrote that preface to Personal Memoirs on July 1, 1883, three weeks before he died. Fighting for the Confederacy: The Personal Recollections of General Edward Porter Alexander has two pages of acknowledgments, but they are those of Gary W. Gallagher, who edited Alexander’s papers. Military Memoirs of a Confederate, General Alexander’s earlier book, has an acknowledgment of sorts under the heading “The Point of View” in the front. It was in this section that the Georgia-born Alexander, known for his courage and candor, made the following admission: One thing remains to be said. The world has not stood still in the years since we took up arms for what we deemed our most valuable right—that of self-government. We now enjoy the rare privilege of seeing what we fought for in the retrospect. It no longer seems so desirable. — Edward Porter Alexander, Military Memoirs of a Confederate: A Critical Narrative (New York: Charles Scribner’s Sons, 1907), p. viii General Alexander’s apostasy caused much tearing of hair and gnashing of teeth below the Mason-Dixon Line. His presence at soirées was no longer as ardently desired.
